abstract.p: Postsecondary transition planning for students with disabilities first entered the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA) in 1990. The required provisions for transition planning were updated with the amendments to IDEA in 1997 and its reauthorization in 2004. Since IDEA 2004 took effect in July 2005, 11 court cases have been decided related to postsecondary transition planning. This article summarizes recent litigation in transition and discuss practice implications.

body.p: Postsecondary outcomes for students with disabilities have been a persistent concern for educators and parents alike. Youths with disabilities often experience poor postschool outcomes. They are more likely to drop out of high school and to be unemployed (or underemployed) than students without disabilities and are less likely to pursue secondary education and live independently (Newman et al., 2011). In 2009, the dropout rate was almost twice as high among students with disabilities compared to their peers without disabilities (15.5% vs. 7.8%), and 80% of youth with disabilities ages 18 to 24 were leaving high school with a credential (Chapman, Laird, Ifill, & Kewal Ramani, 2011). In the area of employment, the U.S. Department of Labor (2011) reported the unemployment rate of persons with a disability as 14.8%, a figure nearly 5.5% higher than the rate for those without a disability (9.4%). Furthermore, in a little more than one decade, the rate of students with disabilities enrolled in postsecondary education almost doubled, from 6% in 1995–1996 to 10.8% in 2007–2008 (U.S. Department of Education, 2011). This article reviews the postsecondary transition requirements of the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act and discusses relevant court cases and due process hearings.

When the Education of All Handicapped Children Act (1975) was reauthorized in 1990 as the Individuals with Disabilities Education Act (IDEA, 1990), it included the requirement of postsecondary transition planning for students with disabilities beginning at age 16. The amendments to IDEA in 1997 required transition planning begin at age 14, with a transition statement regarding the student’s course of study and, at 16 (or younger), a statement of needed transition services with links to outside agencies. In 2004, the Individuals with Disabilities Education Improvement Act further refined the transition requirements for youth with disabilities, including the requirement that transition planning begin at age 16. Each state was required to develop a State Performance Plan that outlined 20 indicators to improve outcomes of children with disabilities (20 U.S.C. 1412(a)(15)(A)(iii)), including postsecondary transition (Indicator 13). Transition is defined as
a coordinated set of activities that (A) is designed to be within a results-oriented process, that is focused on improving the academic and functional achievement of the child with a disability to facilitate the child’s movement from school to post-school activities, including post-secondary education, vocational education, integrated employment (including supported employment), continuing and adult education, adult services, independent living, or community participation; (B) is based on the individual child’s needs, taking into account the child’s strengths, preferences, and interests; and (C) includes instruction, related services, community experiences, the development of employment and other post-school adult living objectives, and, when appropriate, acquisition of daily living skills and functional vocational evaluation. (20 U.S.C. 1402(34))

Transition plans involve the following: (a) student invitation, (b) measurable postsecondary goal(s), (c) age-appropriate transition assessments, (d) coordinated set of activities, (e) outside agency invitation, (f) annual individualized education program (IEP) goal(s), and (g) transfer of rights at age of majority (§300.320(b)).

sec.title: Transition-Related Litigation
sec.p: Considering the level of importance of postschool outcomes for students with disabilities, it is essential for school personnel to understand the implications of relevant case law in service delivery to avoid costly legal involvement and ensure all students’ transition needs are met appropriately. Using electronic and hand searches of the Special Educator from January 1, 2004, to December 31, 2011, the authors found 11 court cases involving postsecondary transition. Of these cases, 8 were decided in favor of the school district and 3 in favor of the parents. Electronic and hand searches of the Special Educator were supplemented with an Internet search to locate 28 state education agency rulings during the same time period. Of those, 12 were decided in favor of districts and 16 were decided in favor of parents.

sec.title: Transition Court Cases
sec.p: Districts generally prevailed in court cases if the child’s transition plan, though generic in nature, allowed the student to receive educational benefit, that is, the plan included the goals of graduating from high school, attending a local university or community college, and attaining future employment in the community (Virginia S. v. Department of Education, 2007). A similar ruling occurred in Rodriguez v. Fort Lee Board of Education (2011). Although the daughter’s transition planning goals were vague and necessary agencies were not invited to the meetings, the court held the school district did not violate the IDEA because it supplied the family with substantial information and assistance. As shown in Table 1, additional case law indicates that districts will not be liable for additional services requested by parents or residential placements as long as the IEP or transition plan provides for a free appropriate public education (FAPE).

caption.p: Court Rulings on Postsecondary Transition in Favor of Schools.

tr.td: Rosinsky v. Green Bay Sch. Dist., 53 IDELR 193 (E.D. Wis. 2009).

The student’s IEP included transition goals related to asking for assistance at job sites without prompting, increasing his independent employability skills, and increasing his independence in a variety of community settings. His mother requested that Alex have 15–20 hours of weekly work in the community.

The court ruled that the transition plan was appropriate; the transition plan with postsecondary transition services statements including course of study, instruction, employment, postschool adult living, daily living, community experiences, functional vocation assessment, related services, and postsecondary goals.
K.C. v. Mansfield Independent School District, 52 IDELR 103 (N.D. Tx. 2009).

An occupational assessment showed the student had both a high interest and a high skill level in the fields of fashion, child care, and child development. The assessment also indicated a high interest in performing arts, but the skill score in that area was in the “very low” range. The parents enrolled their daughter in a private, residential school with a curriculum emphasizing music and functional skills and requested tuition reimbursement.

The court concluded the transition plan reflected the student’s skills and interests, as well as a series of practical goals (e.g., that would help her transition into life after developing a weekly budget, balancing a checking account, conversational skills, and meal preparation) and denied request for reimbursement.
Board of Educ. of Twp. High Sch. Dist. No. 211 v. Ross, 47 IDELR 241 (7th Cir. 2007).
A high school student with Rett syndrome claimed that she was not bound by a settlement that her parents signed when she was a minor.
The 7th Circuit Court denied Lindsey’s new set of claims under the doctrine of claim preclusion (claim preclusion limits original parties from litigating the same claim in a subsequent lawsuit).
Sherri High et al. v. Exeter Township School District, 54 IDELR 17 (E.D. PA 2010).

Her IEP included a postsecondary transition plan requiring her to explore career options, file for accommodations for the PSAT and SAT, and practice completing job applications. Using the Keys to Work research program, the transition coordinator and Stephanie identified career interests in education and health care services; the coordinator arranged job internship and shadowing experiences.

The court upheld the hearing officer’s decision that the district provided an appropriate transition plan for Stephanie because the transition plan included 32 opportunities for transition counseling, transition assessment, job shadowing and internship, assistance with college testing, and career fair attendance.
C.B. on Behalf of E.B., a Child with a Disability vs. Pittsford Central School District, 54 IDELR 149 (W.D.N.Y. 2010).

E.B. received daily services in a resource room, twice monthly occupational therapy, and monthly occupational therapy consultation. Parents complained that the 2007–2008 IEP was essentially the same as the previous IEP and did not provide an appropriate transition plan, including attention to his writing problems.
E.B.’s IEP contained transition planning, including participation in a 10th grade career inventory assessment; the request for additional services was denied.
Richard S. Heller obo N.H., Minor vs. Minn. Dept. of Ed., 54 IDELR 60 (Minn. Ct. App. 2010).
Parents alleged that the district failed to consider an outside evaluation through the Courage Center in favor of the transition evaluation model used by the district.

The court ruled that although parents may have offered appropriate alternative evaluation methods with equal validity, the district is not required to adopt those standards if their current standards are appropriate evaluation methods.

sec.p: In contrast, failure to provide adequate and individualized services to ensure an appropriate education has resulted in parents prevailing in the courts. Specifically, failure to properly assess the student’s vocational skills and address individual needs (e.g., lack of IEP transition goals related to pragmatic language deficits, and failure to allow the student to receive vocational services in the community or services to support independent living) resulted in the court ordering the district to provide compensatory transition services for 2 years (Dracut School Committee v. Bureau of Special Education Appeals, 2010). Similarly, in Klein Independent School District and Texas Education Agency v. Per Hovem, Knut Hovem, and Signe Hovem (2010), the court concluded that the student’s transition plan was neither individualized nor adequate to meet his needs after high school (e.g., writing and spelling abilities were not adequate to attend college) and ordered the school to reimburse the family for 2 years of compensatory education. Finally, although the court agreed that the transition plan clearly outlined transition goals, including development of a plan for life after high school, it lacked appropriate transition-related evaluations, and the student’s IEP was too general. Consequently, the court ordered 5.5 hours of compensatory education for every school day in the 2006–2007 school year to be awarded to the student (School District of Philadelphia v. Deborah A., 2011).

sec.title: State Education Agency Decisions
sec.p: Districts typically prevailed in administrative due process hearings if they had followed procedural safeguards and developed transition plans that enabled the student to receive FAPE by increasing the likelihood of successful transition in postsecondary environments. Districts also prevailed in cases when minor procedural violations were identified, if the district had provided services that afforded the student substantive benefits. In contrast, parents were the prevailing party when the district failed to meet procedural requirements and services provided did not result in substantive educational benefits. Transition plans that were not comprehensive, reflective of the student’s needs, or carefully designed to ensure the successful transition to postsecondary settings were the most frequently cited reasons for ruling in favor of the parents. If the district’s transition planning did not include parental involvement, or if the planning placed the burden of transition responsibilities on the student or parents, then state education agencies (SEAs) decided in the family’s favor. Though required annually, IEP meetings should occur more frequently, if a parent has a concern with the transition plan.

Plans should contain results-oriented, measurable, and appropriate postsecondary goals. The use of multiple transition assessments, updated transition goals when student’s interests changed, and career goals that are consistent with the student’s academic abilities are further safeguards for district personnel. Districts not following these guidelines were often required to pay for compensatory education and services. Table 2 provides a sample of SEA rulings on postsecondary transition in favor of districts. Table 3 provides a sample of SEA rulings on postsecondary transition in favor of parents or guardians.

caption.p: State Education Agency Rulings on Transition in Favor of Schools.

tr.td: Fife Sch. Dist., 45 IDELR 86 (SEA WA 2005)

Parents of a 14-year-old student with dyslexia obtained a private evaluation, rather than one by the school, to guide academic (math) and transition planning because they were concerned about his emotional state.

A hearing officer overrode parents’ refusal of consent when the district demonstrated a legitimate need to evaluate the student in math and vocational assessments because the purposes of the two evaluations were different and the district’s proposed evaluation was “minimally invasive.” The hearing officer determined the purposes of the two evaluations were different and the district’s proposed evaluation was “minimally invasive.”
New York City Dep’t of Educ., 49 IDELR 207 (SEA NY 2008)

The district did not make the postsecondary agency referral until 10 months before the student’s 21st birthday, thus violating a state law requiring the referral be made 12 months prior to when the student turns 21, but did provide appropriate transition goals and services to meet those goals.

The hearing officer ruled the delay in referral was detrimental to the student, but was not a gross violation of IDEA and did not require the district to provide a year’s worth of compensatory education to the student.
In re Student with a Disability, 51 IDELR 89 (SEA NY 2008)
The parents of a high school senior with learning disabilities sought reimbursement for their son’s private placement based on an alleged faulty transition plan stating it was vague.

The hearing officer denied reimbursement noting that the transition plan reflected the student’s interests in business and art, included measurable long-term adult outcomes in community, postsecondary education goals, independent living, and competitive employment.
Los Angeles Unified Sch. Dist., 110 LRP 34448 (SEA CA 2010)
A student with a history of emotional disturbance did not have a written transition plan.
The hearing officer ruled the district may have violated IDEA procedurally but caused no educational harm to the student. She received appropriate transition services at a district charter school.
San Juan Bd. of Coop. Educ. Servs., 55 IDELR 269 (SEA CO 2010)
The parents of an academically successful, college-bound high school student with a specific learning disability alleged the district did not implement an adequate transition plan for their son.

The hearing officer ruled the transition plan appropriately focused on the student’s college goal, and detailed numerous activities to be completed by the student, parents, and case manager to achieve that goal.
Milford Bd. of Educ., 110 LRP 32008 (SEA CT 2010)
The parents of a 20-year-old student with a specific learning disability alleged a Connecticut school district did not provide adequate transition services.

The hearing officer ruled the district complied with IDEA by providing services that would allow the student to enter the workforce in her personal vocational fields of interest (animal care and police work).

fn.p: IDEA = Individuals with Disabilities Education Act.

caption.p: State Education Agency (SEA) Rulings on Transition in Favor of Parents/Guardians.

tr.td: Black River Fall Sch. Dist., 40 IDELR 163 (SEA WI 2004)

The district failed to provide measurable IEP goals and proper transition planning to a 19-year-old student with an emotional/behavioral disorder and ADHD. The district made its graduation determination based on number of credits earned without taking into account the student’s progress on his IEP.

A hearing officer ordered the district to provide services until the student turned 21, to develop a proper transition plan to support the student’s interests in college exploration, obtaining part-time employment, and acquiring daily living skills. The district denied the student FAPE when the only objective criterion of his IEP (grades) failed to show significant progress.
Bethlehem Sch. Dist., 41 IDELR 110 (SEA PA 2004)

A parent of a high school student with reading, math, and speech-language disabilities unilaterally placed his child in a private school, claiming the IEP did not address the child’s disabilities in reading and math or provide transition planning or a means of tracking progress.

The state review panel awarded compensatory education for 540 class periods, reimbursement for the private school placement and travel expenses, as well as reimbursement for the accompanying independent educational evaluation.
Board of Educ. of the Carmel Central Sch. Dist., 43 IDELR 76 (SEA NY 2005)

A 15-year-old student with dyslexia was not given an IEP reflective of her present levels of performance, nor were the goals and objectives reasonably calculated for her to receive educational benefit. The IEP was also deficient because it did not include a transition plan.

A hearing officer decided the IEP developed by the district denied the student FAPE because the IEP was not reflective of her present levels of performance and it did not contain a statement of her transition needs, preferences, and interests; projected postschool or higher education goals; or a statement of transition services.
Board of Educ. of the Newburgh Enlarged City Sch. Dist., 44 IDELR 264 (SEA NY 2005)

The parent of a 17-year-old with multiple disabilities, including cerebral palsy and a visual impairment, alleged the district proposed an out-of-district placement without a representative of the placement present at the IEP meeting.

The hearing officer decided the district denied the student FAPE by convening a placement meeting without the presence of a representative from the proposed out-of-district placement, proposing a program that was no longer offered, and providing for the student’s transitional needs, nor did it address the student’s behavioral needs.
East Hartford Bd. of Educ., 50 IDELR 240 (SEA CT 2008)

The district effectively excluded the parents of a 21-year-old with Down syndrome by determining he no longer required speech services when he did, by stating he would be served with his nondisabled peers for more than 30 hours a week when he was not, and by practicing life skills in a separate classroom rather than the community.

The hearing officer noted several errors in the student’s IEP and transition plan: The student did not receive proper supervision, and his program did not include independent living or community involvement nor support services he needed to succeed. The district was directed to retain an independent consultant and to develop an appropriate compensatory program for the student.
Monrovia Unified Sch. Dist., 108 LRP 40496 (SEA CA 2008)

The plan was based on an occupational interest assessment and a simple one-page “fill in the blanks” form. It identified the student’s general career interests and goals, but did not identify any transition services.

Because the district failed to offer a transition plan that afforded a meaningful educational benefit to the student, the student was denied FAPE. Without actual transition services, a transition plan cannot contain coordinated activities to promote movement from school to postschool activities.
Natick Pub. Schs., 54 IDELR 109 (SEA MA 2010)

A 20-year-old student left high school with a strong interest in sports and broadcasting but had never undergone a comprehensive assessment of vocational skills and interests. The student was placed in a new district program for postsecondary transition.

The district denied the student FAPE by placing him in this program, because the placement did not offer the academic and social opportunities that a he needed to live independently. The district was ordered to reimburse the parents for 2 years of outside educational placement for the student.
District of Columbia Pub. Sch., 111 LRP 26012 (SEA DC 2011)

A foster child’s guardian alleged the district denied the child FAPE because it did not conduct a vocational assessment and failed to develop an age-appropriate transition plan. The plan was generic, did not include developmental courses addressing academic deficits, and did not address college preparation. The guardian sought review of the assessment, revision of the IEP, and compensatory education.

The district failed to use assessment instruments specifically designed to measure the student’s unique abilities and level of functioning. The transition plan was not reasonable, realistic, or attainable. For example, the plan stated an expectation for a career as a forensic scientist, yet the student was performing at a fifth grade level. The district was ordered to provide a vocational assessment and compensatory education in the form of an SAT course, independent tutoring, and career counseling.
Philadelphia Sch. Dist., 111 LRP 34182 (SEA PA 2011)

A student’s transition plan required only that a student attend a fair and career options workshop. The transition plan did not address work, daily living, vocational assessment, or related services; and no individualized objectives were included in the plans.

The district was ordered to provide compensatory education on a full-day basis for a period of 2 years. Because the educational plans were inappropriate, the district was further ordered to provide a special reading program, occupational therapy evaluation, and a new IEP.

fn.p: ADHD = attention-deficit/hyperactivity disorder; FAPE = free appropriate public education; IEP = individualized education program.

sec.title: Implications for Practice
sec.p: The implications of the legal trends on postsecondary transition planning on practice continue to be limited by the lack of a national court decision. Although these court cases reflect a variety of jurisdictions in the federal court system, it is important to note that the case law may not be binding. For example, 7th Circuit rulings are binding in Illinois, Indiana, and Wisconsin only. These cases, nonetheless, present a powerful argument for consideration because of the precedence they establish. In keeping with the requirements of IDEA (2004), it is imperative that school personnel provide transition plans for students with disabilities no later than when the student turns 16 (unless state requirements begin at an earlier age). District- and state-level special education should provide ongoing professional development for teachers, guidance counselors, building-level administrators, and job coaches in the following areas: (a) IEP development tools, (b) transition assessment and planning, and (c) career assessment. The National Secondary Transition Technical Assistance Center (2012) has provided a battery of products and resources related to postsecondary transition at its website (www.nsttac.org).

Although IDEA does not require states to guarantee any particular educational outcome, it does require the provision of special education and related services to be carefully designed to allow the child to benefit from special education (Board of Education v. Rowley, 1982; Yell, Katsiyannis, & Hazelkorn, 2007). In addition, the student’s transition plan must be reasonably calculated to provide FAPE when it reflects the student’s skills and interests, including practical goals and objectives based on multiple individual assessments that will help the student transition to preferred life trajectories after high school. To further assist with this transition, IDEA 2004 requires a summary of performance when students are no longer eligible for special education services because of high school graduation with a standard diploma or because the student has exceeded age restrictions. To help school districts meet this requirement in a consistent manner, the Council for Exceptional Children (CEC, 2012) has developed a summary of performance model checklist. Part 1 includes the student’s demographic information and contact information and the results from his or her most recent formal and informal assessment reports as documentation of the disability. Part 2 lists the student’s postsecondary goals. Part 3 covers three important areas: academic, cognitive, and functional levels of performance, including the accommodations, modifications, and assistive technology that were critical in high school to help the student make appropriate progress. Included in Part 4, Recommendations to Assist the Student in Meeting Postsecondary Goals, are suggestions for additional accommodations and services that would be helpful to the student in higher education, training and/or employment, independent living, or community participation. It is highly recommended that the student with a disability complete Part 5, Student Input, for the purposes of self-advocacy and self-determination (CEC, 2012).

sec.title: Future Directions
sec.p: Future court cases will define both transition and evidence-based practices to promote improved postsecondary outcomes (i.e., education/training, employment, and independent living). In February 2011, Rep. Gregg Harper (R-MS) introduced H.R. 602, The Transition Toward Excellence, Achievement, and Mobility Through Education Act (TEAM), with transition planning age starting at 14. Provisions of the bill include the following: (a) advocates training in self-advocacy and self-determination to increase student empowerment, (b) targets students with significant disabilities who would typically require significant support in an employment setting that pays minimum wage or higher, and (c) prohibits the use of facility-based employment or activity settings, such as sheltered workshops, day habilitation centers, mobile work crews, or enclave work settings in a child’s IEP (U.S. Congress, 2011). No action has been taken on this bill beyond its introduction on the floor.

In addition, IDEA (2004) requires “a statement of the special education and related services and supplementary aids and services, based on peer-reviewed research to the extent practicable, to be provided to the child” (Section 614 (d)(1)(A)(i)(IV)). This requirement for evidence-based practices certainly applies to transition services. Though there are no cases addressing the empirical support of transition-related interventions, there is a reasonable expectation that such cases will emerge. School districts will be well served if they implement evidence-based practices for transition. Specifically, transition programs should be comprehensive in nature and address a variety of postschool outcomes and begin with the appropriate academic courses (e.g., participation in the general education curriculum, as well as courses that target specific skills, such as functional mathematics). In addition, transition programs should include self-determination skills, social skills, and career instruction and experiences.

Self-determination is a dispositional characteristic defined as the ability to act as the “primary causal agent in one’s life” (Wehmeyer, 1996, p. 24). People who are self-determined are able to take action to achieve their desired quality of life without the undue influence or interference of others. They demonstrate the essential elements of self-determination: autonomy, self-regulation, self-realization, and psychological empowerment (Wehmeyer, 1996). Research has indicated that increased levels of self-determination are associated with increased performance in postsecondary education (Harris & Robertson, 2001), employment, and independent living (Chambers et al., 2007). Self-determination can be taught by addressing its component skills (e.g., goal setting and attainment skills, decision-making skills, self-awareness, self-knowledge, self-efficacy, self-advocacy and leadership skills, problem-solving skills) and through developed programs such as the Self-Determined Learning Model of Instruction (Wehmeyer, Palmer, Argan, Mithaug, & Martin, 2000) and NEXT S.T.E.P.: Student Transition and Educational Planning (Halpern, Herr, Wolf, Doren, & Johnson, 1997).

Another transition practice that schools should consider implementing is social skills instruction. Students who demonstrate higher-level social skills are more likely to attend postsecondary education institutions and be employed as adults (Test et al., 2009). Specific social skills, such as maintaining conversations, may be taught individually or in group settings through modeling, role-playing, rehearsal, video training, and cue cards (Alwell & Cobb, 2009). In addition, a number of social skill curricula can be purchased, such as Skillstreaming the Adolescent (McGinnis, 2011), The EQUIP Program (Gibbs, Potter, & Goldstein, 1995), and The ACCEPTS Program (Walker et al., 1988).

Career instruction and experiences are a critical component in transition programs. Landmark, Ju, and Zhang (2010) reported work experience and employment preparation to be the two most substantiated transition practices. Those practices, along with career assessment and occupational courses, have been associated with increased postsecondary attendance, employment, and independent living (Test et al., 2009). Schools can implement this practice through vocational education, providing assessments to help students select potential occupations, work-study programs, and internships.

sec.title: Conclusion
sec.p: Effective transition remains a critical component in affording qualified students with disabilities an appropriate education. Over the years, legislative requirements have not only articulated the responsibility of school districts in ensuring the seamless and effective transitioning of students to postsecondary environments but also increased the nature and extent of the schools’ responsibility. Case law discussed in light of this review demonstrates that there is a challenge in ensuring the adequacy of transition services. Furthermore, current employment, postsecondary education, and independent living outcomes are far from acceptable. Consequently, school districts must intensify the implementation of evidence-based practices to improve the effectiveness of transition services and ultimately the lives of those with disabilities.
